awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Murray and his group at Louisiana State University and Agricultural and Mechanical College in Baton Rouge will develop new instrumentation for rapid chemical and biochemical analysis under ambient conditions. The instruments developed under this project will have applications in forensics, transportation security, medicine, and other diverse areas. Dr. Murray's group will use pulsed infrared lasers to ablate material directly from samples in the environment. The ablated material is captured in a small solvent droplet or on a sample target for mass spectrometry analysis. Unlike conventional mass spectrometry, the bulk sample does not need to be processed and loaded into the instrument; the laser removes only a small portion for analysis. The dual goals of the research are a fundamental understanding of the infrared laser ablation process and the application of this knowledge to the design and implementation of novel chemical analysis instrumentation. The fundamental issues of laser ablation are the size and quantity of the ablated material and the dependence on the laser wavelength, pulse energy, and sample composition. High-speed photography, broad-spectrum particle sizing, and finite element modeling will be used to probe and optimize the material removal process. Ambient laser ablation sampling will be used for biochemical imaging and remote robotic sampling. Laser ablation sampling allows component separation between sampling and analysis for expanded dynamic range. The remote robotic sampling stage will sample large three-dimensional objects for diverse applications such as real-time mass spectrometry during a surgical procedure or checkpoint baggage analysis for explosive residue.

 The educational component of this project continues the focus on expanding educational opportunities for underrepresented groups that is the highlight of the LSU chemistry program. A hands-on mass spectrometry demonstration will also be developed that will show students the power and utility of mass spectrometry while linking to the fundamental chemistry and physics behind the technique.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was the development of a new method for sampling biomolecules in tissue that has applications in research, clinical diagnosis, and treatment of ailments such as cancer, neurodegenerative diseases, and brain injury. When a pulsed laser hits a material, it can remove molecules by desorption of molecules, or ablation of particles, and can create ions for mass spectrometry. Demonstrating that a laser can produce ions from large biomolecules such as proteins was one of the most important advances in chemical analysis in the past several decades. The low fragmentation method of matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization is highly useful due to its ability to detect large biomolecules for imaging applications. However, direct ionization from tissue limits the accessible concentration range and the ability to detect low abundance species. This project developed a new method for mass spectrometry analysis that allows the separation of the chemical components in the sample so that even low concentration, and potentially important, biomolecules can be detected. We used an infrared laser to ablate tissue that was collected for chromatographic or electrophoretic separation and detailed mass spectrometry analysis. A central component of this project was aimed at improving the fundamental understanding of tissue laser ablation and using that knowledge to help develop instruments and techniques in biomedical imaging.


Two new techniques were developed in this project. The first used the laser to remove biomolecules from a surface that were captured in a flowing solution that went into the mass spectrometer to create ions for mass analysis. The second technique used the laser to ablate tissue that was captured in a solution. The captured proteins were then digested and the fragments were analyzed in a mass spectrometer. The masses of the fragments were used to identify the proteins in different parts of the tissue. Our technique is faster and more efficient than currently available techniques that sample proteins in tissue.  


The best way to build better instruments for chemical analysis is to understand the chemical and physical processes that make them work. For this project, we developed a new system for measuring the amount and size of particles produced by laser ablation of tissue. The system combines two particle size measuring instruments: one uses light scattering to detect large particles, the other uses particle mobility to detect small particles. Together they can measure particles ranging from the size of a dust spec down to a cluster of a few thousand molecules. We can tune the particle size with the laser energy and wavelength to achieve the best efficiency for sampling biomolecules for tissue imaging.


The educational goals of this project continue the commitment of Louisiana State University to undergraduate and graduate student education and to post-doctoral training. Louisiana State University leads the nation in granting doctoral degrees in chemistry to women and underrepresented minorities. A classroom demonstration of plasmas and discharges was developed using cathode and anode ray tubes and light and mass spectrometers to illustrate the concepts of energy and ion formation. The Wikipedia Education Program website was used to develop freely available open source content for mass spectrometry classes. Educational materials developed as part of this project were posted to Wikimedia Commons and are freely available for education and research use.
